introduction.p: In this section, we introduce a new mathematical tool called a logarithm, which will help us solve exponential equations. Much the same way as a square root "undoes" the squaring function, a logarithm undoes an exponential function.

subsection.title: A Logarithm is an Exponent
subsection.p: Suppose that a colony of bacteria doubles in size every day. If the colony starts with 50 bacteria, how long will it be before there are 800 bacteria?

We answer questions of this type by writing and solving an exponential equation. The initial value of the population is P_0=50, and the growth factor is 2. Thus, the function P(t) = 50 \cdot 2^t gives the number of bacteria present on day t, and we must solve the equation 800 = 50 \cdot 2^t We are looking for an unknown exponent on base 2. Dividing both sides by 50 yields 16 = 2^t This equation asks the question: "To what power must we raise 2 in order to get 16?"

Because 2^4 = 16, we see that the solution of the equation is 4. You can check that t=4 solves the original problem: P(\alert{4}) = 50 \cdot 2^{\alert{4}} = 800 The unknown exponent that solves the equation 16=2^t is called the base 2 logarithmlogarithm of 16. The exponent in this case is 4, and we write this fact as \log_{2}(16) = 4 In other words, we solved an exponential equation by computing a logarithm. We make the following definition.

statement.p: For b\gt 0~ and ~b\ne 1,
the base b logarithm of xbase is the exponent to which b must be raised in order to yield x.
We write the logarithm as \log_{b} {(x)}.

subsection.p: From the definition of a logarithm and the examples above, we see that the following two statements are equivalent.

assemblage.title: Logarithms and Exponents: Conversion Equations
assemblage.p: If b \gt 0, b\ne 1, and x \gt 0, \blert{y = \log_b {(x)}}~~~ \text{ if and only if }~~~ \blert{ x = b^y}

subsection.p: This equivalence tells us that the logarithm, y, is the same as the exponent in x = b^y. We see again that a logarithm is an exponent; it is the exponent to which b must be raised to yield x.
For example, to convert the equation 3 = \log_5 {(125)} to exponential form, we note that the base is b=5 and the logarithm is y=3, so the exponent on base 5 will be 3, like this: 125 = 5^3.
The conversion equations allow us to convert from logarithmic to exponential form, or vice versa. It will help you to become familiar with the conversion, because we will use it frequently.
As special cases of the equivalence above, we can compute the following useful logarithms.

assemblage.title: Some Useful Logarithms

subsection.title: Logs and Exponential Equations
subsection.p: We use logarithms to solve exponential equations, just as we use square roots to solve quadratic equations. Consider the two equations x^2 = 25 ~~~~ \text{ and } ~~~~ 2^x = 8 We solve the first equation by taking a square root, and we solve the second equation by computing a logarithm: x = \pm\sqrt{25} = \pm 5 ~~~~ \text{ and } ~~~~ x = \log_{2}{(8)} = 3 The operation of taking a base b logarithm is the inverse operation for raising the base b to a power, just as extracting square roots is the inverse of squaring a number.

Every exponential equation can be rewritten in logarithmic form by using the conversion equations. Thus, 3 = \log_{2}{(8)}~~~~ \text{ and }~~~~ 8 = 2^3 are equivalent statements, just as 5 = \sqrt{25}~~~~ \text{ and }~~~~ 25 = 5^2 are equivalent statements. Rewriting an equation in logarithmic form is a basic strategy for finding its solution.

subsection.title: Approximating Logarithms
subsection.p: Now let's consider computing logarithms that are not obvious by inspection. Suppose we would like to solve the equation 2^x = 26 The solution of this equation is x = \log_{2}{(26)}, but can we find a decimal approximation for this value? There is no integer power of 2 that equals 26, because 2^4 = 16~~~~~ \text{and }~~~~ 2^5 = 32 So \log_{2}{(26)} must be between 4 and 5. We can use trial and error to find the value of \log_{2}{(26)} to the nearest tenth. Use your calculator to make a table of values for y = 2^x, starting with x = 4 and using increments of 0.1.
From the table we see that 26 is between 2^{4.7} and 2^{4.8}, and is closer to 2^{4.7}. To the nearest tenth, \log_{2}{(26)} \approx 4.7.
Trial and error can be a time-consuming process. In the next Example we illustrate a graphical method for estimating the value of a logarithm.

statement.p: Approximate \log_{3}{(7)} to the nearest hundredth.

solution.p: If \log_{3}{(7)}=x, then 3^x = 7. We will use the graph of y = 3^x to approximate a solution to 3^x = 7.

We graph Y_1 =3 X and Y_2 = 7 in the same window to obtain the graph shown below. Next we activate the intersect feature to find that the two graphs intersect at the point (1.7712437, 7). Because this point lies on the graph of y = 3^x , we know that 3^{1.7712437} \approx 7~~~\text{, or }~~~ \log_{3}{(7)} \approx 1.7712437 To the nearest hundredth, \log_{3}{(7)} \approx 1.77.

subsection.title: Base 10 Logarithms
subsection.p: Some logarithms are used so frequently in applications that their values are programmed into scientific and graphing calculators. These are the base 10 logarithms, such as \log_{10}{(1000)} = 3 ~~~\text{ and }~~~ \log_{10}{(0.01)} = -2 Base 10 logarithms are called common logarithmscommon logarithmsbase 10 logarithmscommon logarithmslogarithmscommon (base 10), and the subscript 10 is often omitted, so that \log {(x)} is understood to mean \log_{10}{(x)}.

subsection.p: To evaluate a base 10 logarithm, we use the LOG key on a calculator. Many logarithms are irrational numbers, and the calculator gives as many digits as its display allows. We can then round off to the desired accuracy.

li.p: The keying sequence LOG 6.5 )ENTER yields .812913566, so \log {(6.5)} \approx 0.81.
The keying sequence LOG 256 ) ENTER yields 2.408239965, so \log {(256)} \approx 2.41.

note.p: We can check the approximations found in with our conversion equations. Remember that a logarithm is an exponent, and in this example the base is 10. We find that \amp\amp 10^{0.81} \amp\approx 6.45654229 \text{and} \amp\amp 10^{2.41} \amp\approx 257.0395783 so our approximations are reasonable, although you can see that rounding a logarithm to 2 decimal places does lose some accuracy.
For this reason, rounding logarithms to 4 decimal places is customary.

subsection.title: Solving Exponential Equations
subsection.p: We can now solve any exponential equation with base 10.

statement.p: Solve the equation ~~38 = 95 - 15 \cdot 10^{0.4x}

solution.p: First, we isolate the power of 10: We subtract 95 from both sides of the equation and divide by -15 to obtain -57 \amp = -15 \cdot 10^{0.4x} \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide by }-15.} 3.8 \amp = 10^{0.4x} Next, we convert the equation to logarithmic form as \log_{10}{(3.8)} = 0.4x Solving for x yields \frac{\log_{10}{(3.8)}}{0.4}= x We can evaluate this expression on the calculator by entering
which yields 1.449458992. Thus, to four decimal places, x \approx 1.4495.

warning.p: Do not omit the parenthesis when entering the expression in . Without the parenthesis, you are calculating \log_{10}{\left(\dfrac{3.8}{0.4}\right)}. You can check that this is not the same as \dfrac{\log_{10}{(3.8)}}{0.4}.

subsection.title: Application to Exponential Models
subsection.p:
We have seen that exponential functions are used to describe some applications of growth and decay, P(t) = P_0b^t. There are two common questions that arise in connection with exponential models:
Given a value of t, what is the corresponding value of P(t)?
Given a value of P(t), what is the corresponding value of t?
To answer the first question, we evaluate the function P(t) at the appropriate value. To answer the second question, we must solve an exponential equation, and this usually involves logarithms.
